#Text=Rainy River
#Text=Rainy
#Text=River
#Text=is a town of 842 people ( 2011 ) in Northern Ontario .
#Text=It exists primarily as an entry point between Northern Ontario , Canada , and Northwestern Minnesota , United States of America .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Rainy River sits southeast of Lake of the Woods on the eponymous Rainy River , which forms part of the Ontario-Minnesota segment of the Canada – US border .
#Text=Opposite Rainy River across the river is the town of Baudette , Minnesota .
#Text=The two towns are connected by the Baudette – Rainy River International Bridge .
#Text=Rainy River is at the northwestern terminus of Ontario Highway 11 .

#Text=Rainy River is famous for being frequently ( though wrongly ) seen as being at being the opposite end of Toronto 's Yonge Street , which has led to the street being dubbed the " longest street in the world " , due to a false conflation between the street and Highway 11 , which the street was once the southernmost section of .
#Text=The street name for the highway through the town is Atwood Avenue .
#Text=History

#Text=Rainy River was formed around 1895 along the east shore of the Rainy River about 2 km from the current town centre by a group of lumbermen whose mill was purchased by the Beaver Mills Lumber Company in 1898 .
#Text=The small village took the name Beaver Mills until it was incorporated as a town in 1904 .

#Text=In 1901 the Ontario and Rainy River Railway completed a bridge connecting Minnesota to Ontario , but Beaver Mills town site was in the way of the eastern end and so they created a new town further up river in between the two large mills .
#Text=The only method of transport at the time was by steamship so parts of the bridge arrived addressed to " Rainy River " .
#Text=The town eventually accepted this as its name .
#Text=The town grew rapidly because of the thriving lumber industry and its two large mills and bolstered by the railway .
#Text=In 1910 , a forest fire known as The Great Fire of 1910 originating in northern Minnesota swept north and destroyed the mills .

#Text=Across the south side of the river the two villages of Baudette and Spooner were completely burned out , and much of the population was saved at the last moment by a group of citizens from Rainy River who backed a train of box cars across the bridge and pulled them out .
#Text=The mill industry relocated as a result , contributing to a drop in population from more than 2000 people to its current less than 800 .
#Text=Because of the railway ( now a part of Canadian National Railways ) , the growing hunting/fishing tourism industry , the town remained firmly established .

#Text=The town has had many industries in the past , a Rail Round House , in the 1960s the Rainy River Boat company , in the 1970s Arctic Cat Apparel among some of the major ones , all have now closed and the current town faces a dismal future .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Highway 11 ends in Rainy River , at the bridge to the USA .
#Text=From Winnipeg : its 265 km , take Highway 1 southeast to Highway 12 , head south through Steinbach to the U.S. border , then Minnesota 312 to Minnesota 11 to the border crossing at Gaudette .
#Text=See
#Text=Tomahawk Island Lighthouse , 647 Lighthouse Road , Sleeman .
#Text=Su - F 8AM-6PM .
#Text=Built in 1901 .
#Text=10 m tall .
#Text=Moved 8 km to the mainland by its private owners in the 1960s .
#Text=Kay-Nah-Chi-Wah-Nung Historical Centre ( Manitou Mounds ) ( Place of the Long Rapids ) , 340 Ross Road , Stratton ( 33 km from Rainy River ) , ☏ +1807 483-1163 .
#Text=Late May to mid-Oct : W - Su 11AM-6PM ; Jan-Apr : F noon-5PM , Sa Su 9AM-5PM .
#Text=One of the most significant centres of early habitation and ceremonial burial in Canada .

#Text=The centre is owned and operated by Rainy River First Nations and offers interpretive tours and galleries , a collections space with over 16,000 artifacts , a gift shop that showcases artwork by local Indigenous artists , and a restaurant that serves traditional Ojibway cuisine .
#Text=Learn about Ojibway history , language , geography , culture , and traditions .
#Text=These lands hold the record of more than 8,000 years of recurring use or habitation and contains the largest group of burial mounds in North America .
#Text=Fully accessible .
#Text=There are golf cart tours to the largest burial mound which is over 5 km away .
#Text=There are 22 burial mounds .
#Text=They have bicycles as well .
#Text=Guided tours : adults $ 12 , seniors and children $ 8 ; self-guided : $ 5 .
#Text=Do

#Text=A fishing tournament , held in September - since 1998 .
